thinking.disposable_income: Roseland has a median household income of approximately $37,000, significantly below Chicago's average. About 24% of residents live below poverty level, indicating limited disposable income for many households
thinking.discretionary_consumption: Given the low median income, residents have limited discretionary spending capacity. Many households spend a large portion of income on necessities, making them sensitive to additional taxes and transportation costs
thinking.accessibility: Roseland is served by Metra Electric District line and several CTA bus routes, but transit service is less frequent compared to North Side communities. About 70% of households own cars, though many are transit-dependent. Average commute times are longer than city average
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritize lower transit fares ($0.75) due to high proportion of transit-dependent residents and low income levels. 2. Prefer lower sales tax (0.5-1.0%) to minimize impact on already limited discretionary spending. 3. Support moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without overly burdening car-dependent households. 4. Balance between improved transit times and affordable fares. 5. Consider proposals that reduce both transit and driving times to benefit all residents
